												Portal was, in short; short. It taught you how to play the game through a series of levels, and when you were finally trained, the game ended. It was much too easy and lacked much intellect. This game was the preparation of what would be the greatest puzzle video game of all-time (Portal 2). It needed to be the first, so that every flaw in it would be ironed out by the time of Portal 2. Even after all these insults, it was still amazing. It was very funny, had a new and interesting concept behind it, it was quotable, and best of all, memorable.

												Where do I even begin?Well for starters this came out in 2007 and uses the source physics engine which is very powerful. And if you don't know already, it is in the same story line of Half Life.Story: This game has a beautiful story that shows you what can happen when you have a unstable super-computer incontrol of a futuristic science facilty that houses many advanced devices that need testing and that actually sounds bat♥♥♥♥♥♥crazy. The story shows you affection, signs of insanity, betrayal and much more and has a lot of testing courses. The test chambers are great and have enough things in them to be tough, but tough enough where you want to solve it instead of quiting.Physics/portals: The portal gun is great and really shows off what the physics engine can do. You can also use the engine and do the chambers in different ways using different methods using physics. Also, you may think that "Well you can place a portal anywhere..." and well, that's wrong and that gives me a challenge because I always want to shoot less and less portals to do the chamber...Graphics: The graphics back then, were good, but not amazing. It uses textures that look like Half Life 2's, but that is because they are on the same Earth. Everything loads great, but sometimes I'll think to myself and say that some textures need a face lift.Sounds: The sounds are great and I have never thought to myself that one sound wouldn't go with that item/object or device.Voice acting: The voice acting is great. The woman that did GlaDos' voice did a real great job and you really do think that it is a computer talking to you. Same thing with the turrets, since they say things as if what they are saying is what they are programed to say.Final verdict: 94/100 This game is great on so many levels and the only thing that stops it from getting 100/100 is that the story doesn't go in depth of Apeture science until Portal 2 and sure they did go more in depth in Portal 2, but Valve could have done it in Portal.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												This game is very awesome. Seriously how can anyone not like this. Besically, the story goes like this:You play as Chell, a silent but determined test subject who is trapped in Aperture Science. The facility is run by a psychotic AI named GLaDOS(Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System) who makes Chell go through some deadly tests involving a gun that shoots portals(the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, or as I like to call it "ASHPoD"). They're easy as first, but as you progress they get harder. During testing, GLaDOS promises Chell things like cake and grief counseling. However, after Chell discovers some graffitti revealing the AI's true intentions, Chell is skeptical of this so called "reward". After dodging adorable but deadly turrets, flinging through portals, and incinerating a cute box, you finally make it to the last test chamber. I would tell you what happens after that, but I don't want to spoil the surprise. Portal has a great storyling, great characters, great graphics, and amazing gameplay. I definetly recommend this.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Portal is my favorite game of all time, uncontested. I've completed it about 12 times. It's definitly the smartest game ever created, but it's also very short. I like this game much better than I like Portal 2. Portal 2 was almost a comedy game, while Portal 1 is more ambient and dark, and in the last four test chambers  the Ratman Dens makes it feel sort of a horror game, and soundtracks like Self Esteem Fund really makes it feel like you're alone. I had to take a walk after I played the game for my first time, just to see people again. I love this game and I'd really like Portal 3 if/when it comes out to be more like Portal 1 than Portal 2. Don't get me wrong, Portal 2 is an awesome game, but Portal 1 remains the better game. If you've never played this, give it a go, and if you've already beaten it, go play it again!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												The cake is a lie! However, the hype behind Portal is not.  When I first installed this game, years ago, I was too young and too impatient to appreciate the nuanced and intellectual puzzles that are the heart of the gameplay of this title.  If you take a little time, you'll find something very original and stimulating, and funny.   If you don't like to get frustrated, or if you are the type that gives up easily on a puzzle and searches for the answer...you won't find this game to be fun.If you have the patience to inspect, re-inspect, and re-re-inspect a room for that one puzzle element you missed, or didn't think about, and you have the wish to be rewarded and have the "EUREKA!" moment when you finally realize that bit of wall hanging at an odd angle isn't there just for show...and you, in fact, have to teleport in a loop of gravitational frenzy to catapult yourself from said wall across an impossible chasm into the hands of awaiting freedom (not), then you'll love it!  It's all about the intelligence.  Artificial, or otherwise.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Portal review:Having already heard many good things about portal in the form and video reviews and word of mouth, I can confirm that you will not be disappointed. Portal is a challenging physics based game that shows off in the best possible way. Having said that the game isn't very long, having taken about 3:30 hours to finish it. I wasn't, however left unsatisfied. Portal was a simple yet challenging game that really gave me a sense of achievement having completed it. With the addition of bonus maps there is still plenty of work to be done after the main story line is finished.The story line itself is intricately with a lot of hidden secrets that's it is completely up to the player to find, adding another level to the game.All in all a fantastic idea coupled with a fantastic story line.. Making for a fantastic gameMy rating:Length:8/10Gameplay:10/10All round enjoyment:10/10

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												/ Don't believe anything they tell you about the cake. It's a lie. /This game definitely is a must-have. One of the best games I've played so far. I really enjoyed (and still enjoy) playing this. It's a game everyone could enjoy, in my opinion. The storyline itself took me about 2 to 3 hours to complete. The additional challenges and advanced chambers are nice features, great for adding some game time and a challenge for those who like getting all achievements.The chambers and puzzles get harder smoothly as you advance through the game.  However, it can get a tiny bit repetitive. The portal mechanism really makes this game unique. I really love the smooth physics. Good graphics. The music and sound are okay. The dialog is simply brilliant and hilarious. Through the game, there are several nice additions (random radios playing the catchy theme song, messages from other test subjects) which caused me to laugh from time to time.Portal 2, the sequel, is in my opinion even better, but you just have to play Portal before you start on the sequel. Together, they're a masterpiece.I highly recommend buying this game. It's definitely worth the money. If it's in sale, do not hesitate and buy it immediately (bonus points if you buy Portal 2 too)!

content:
Posted: November 14, 2012
												Portal is in many ways a strange game. At it's core it's a puzzle game, not something most people would consider mainstream but through a great sense of innovation as well as some truly inspired writing it somehow manages to pull it off.The concept of Portal is simple enough. You progress through a series of rooms. In each room you must get from the entrance to the exit overcoming whatever obstacles and dangers might be in there using nothing but your trusty portal gun. The portal gun, quite simply, "shoots" a portal entrance onto a flat surface which allows you to travel through it.This fairly simple concept does get quite a bit more tricky as you progress through the game as moving platforms, lasers, turrets and many other troublesome entities try to stop you.Throughout the game you are accompanied by the sometimes scolding, somethings taunting and sometimes soothing voice of G.L.A.D.O.S. The AI in charge of your training and who might be a little mentally unstable as you'll soon discover. Although G.L.A.D.O.S is the only voice you'll hear in the game she does a fantastic job of keeping your entertained throughout your journey. The humor is some of the best you'll see in a game and the storyline is interesting enough that you'll pay attention to every little tidbit you encounter.The only negative to be mentioned is the very short length of the game that leaves you wanting more. Sadly, the only alternative to replaying the game and pretending to be surprised is the challenges which are fairly boring rinse and repeat because of their extremely unforgiving nature.Portal is a great game and one that any Steam user should have in his library, not just because it's been given away for free to all users not once, but twice. But because it is a truly impressive game experience.

												I enjoyed this game quite a bit. While it isn't long by any means, it isn't supposed to be. Rather, it's supposed to be a game that you can complete within a few hours. Here's a list of some of the things you will encounter/do in Portal within said hours:- Think with portals - Cubes- Incinerators- Buttons- Bigger Buttons- Energy Pellets- Judgemental yet humorous Artificial Intelligence- Remove cameras from walls- Energy Grids- Utilize Newton's Law Of Momentum- Testing- CakeSeriously though, if you are a fan of short yet fun puzzle games, get this one. You will not be disappointed.9/10 (Oh, and great music. Let's not forget that. :3)

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 | 2 *3*] = ~88% (75%-100%)A great 1st person puzzle game, and a great example of how some glimpses of things behind the scenes can add up to a story with quite desirable emotional content. (That's all I say because spoilers.) Portal's content, graphics, sounds, story, tech deserve a firm thumbs-up with both hands.Portal is a great example of non-Euclidean geometry in a game. You enter a hole in the wall, but you don't end up on the other side of the wall, and even the visual appearance behaves accordingly.OTHER GAMES WITH PORTALS / "PREY"Narbacular Drop[www.digipen.edu] by Nuclear Monkey Software was the prototype game with user-placeable portals that lead to the creation of Portal, and (most of?) that team ended up on Valve's Portal team. That game is also worth a play.But the first game I know of that used portal technology was Prey[en.wikipedia.org] (2006), a really good 1st person shooter. Incidentally, I bought it for €1 in a German retail store a few days ago (but had played it before; those were the days when you installed a DVD without having to download anything else), so I know that it's sadly not available on Steam.With little config file editing, Prey runs on 1920x1080, at least that's what I set in the file, but what I saw on screen rather looked like 4K for some reason. Maybe it was indeed 4K contrary to my choice because to achieve custom resolutions, you also have to set a screen mode variable, and maybe this leads to the game using desktop resolution.I had to turn off anti-aliasing because the frame-rate was not fluid even though my machine can't be the reason - must be the old engine. Frame-rate is fluid without AA, and I didn't miss the AA, so it probably was indeed 4K.Config file editing allows to set arbitrary FoV.I played a few minutes on Windows 10 with August 2016 anniversary update on a GTX980.So, if you can get your hands on Prey today (2016), you can still play it very well, and it's still a great game. And even though it's the first non-Euclidean-geometry game (that I know of), it's very already very well done.

												Something about cake and cupcakes or whatever. The cake meme might be the Internet equivalent of a Roman fresco, but this game will forever remain a timeless classic.Portal is a short but sweet first person puzzle game, with great writing, intelligent pacing, and a truly sublime main mechanic that was all the more stunning when it first came out in 2007. It was also one of the 5 titles in the Orange Box collection, which was my personal introduction to Valve games. And it's still good.Advanced levels and level challenges are available once you've finished the main story. There is also rudimentary custom level support (no Steam Workshop here) with plenty of custom levels to be found on the internet.No multiplayer though, and nothing like the gels, lasers and light bridges from Portal 2 - but maybe we don't need those here.Buy this if you like good games and gaming history.

												Portal is one of the best... kinda first-person shooter games out there, without actually shooting any bullets. (Is it a fps? Well, that´s debatable.) The game most certainly is a puzzle game, so your gonna have to use your brain on this one. Portal is a game that will challenge your MIND. So unlike in most games, you have to actually think while playing this... and think ALOT. This kinda challenge can be very tricky in a video game and can easily ruin the gameplay, but the Portal does just the opposite: The gameplay is fun because it´s challenging! The game is just enough difficult to be competitive in a good way, the feeling you get when clearing a difficult level without any help is super rewarding experience! Add this with GlaDOS and a portal gun (which is, let´s be real here: one of the coolest "weapon" in a world of gaming) and you have a super joyful, challenging and unique game, that is an absolute must-have jewel in your library.4/5 This game has the best credits i have ever seen

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to take part in cutting edge scientific experiments that may or may not be unethical? Well then this might be the game for you.First of all the puzzle platforming portal performs plays perfectly……… Um, yes it’s highly addictive and once you overcome every challenge you won’t be able to help yourself but to finish another. The unique portal gun is awesome; creating wormholes through space is amazing fun. When I started playing this game I had high hopes and I was not disappointed. It may be fairly old now but it stands up to the test of time very well.The game is challenging but fair, if you die you know it was your fault. You will on occasion breeze through one room only to be stumped by the next. The peaks and troughs in the learning curve help to vary things up and keep the game interesting, plus beating a room that is difficult feels really good, I had a great time figuring out all the levels and how to get from point A to B. The story is sparse but I get the feeling that was only to add to the constant isolation you feel whilst traversing the Aperture Science Laboratories. The antagonist GLaDOS, whom is really the main character, is fantastic. She has all the witty comments and snide remarks you could want in an evil AI gone mad. Chell the hero remains silent throughout, yet I still ended up connecting with her and her struggle for survival. You should get this game especially if it’s on sale; I thoroughly enjoyed this and the sequel. Have fun ^_^ Oh and the cake is a lie

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Anyone born this side of the Second World War should know enough about Portal to make a judgement for themselves on whether to buy this game, and that judgement should, of course, be to do it. What it lacks in content (you could quite easily finish this game, and all the achievements, in two hours), it makes up for in ingenuity. The portal-gun system is a refreshing element which requires you in many cases to subvert typical puzzle-solving instincts and instead "think with portals", as the game advises. Once you wrap your head around the mechanics though, the puzzles rarely offer a reasonably-quick-witted individual a sufficient challenge. Occasionally, a curveball will be thrown in, but each test chamber is little more than a moment's contemplation away from ephihany. Regular FPS players will find the quicker-paced sections of portal-shooting fun, but short lived if you're sure with your aim, and frustating if you're not. The game's main strength comes from it's humour, which is plentifully provided for by the game's "narrator", GlaDoS, though the story behind it isn't fully realised until Portal 2, which is, overall, a MUCH better game. Still, don't let that put you off. I was glad I bought this, and I'd recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Portal is a game that gets you thinking with portals. You are being tested with portals and you have to solve various puzzles. It's a wonderful game, although it's a short one. It takes around an hour to complete.The graphics don't need to be hyper realistic and actually aren't far off from the sequel of this game, 'Portal 2'.The puzzles aren't the hardest things in the world, and are also often based off of momentum, or to describe it simply, "speedy thing goes in, speedy thing comes out."Though, the difficulty of the puzzles doesn't mean you won't die. Some puzzles will cause your death on the first try, but when you finally reach the moment when your mind figures out how to do this certain puzzle, the feeling is simply awesome.There are slight tricks that the robotic AI, GLaDOS says/does, one example is the promise of cake. She says "You will be baked, and there will be cake", which basically means that she will attempt to kill you with fire.Those tricks are nice and will cause you to listen to that part again to see if you heard it incorrectly or not. Ultimately, this is quite an exceptional game.Short version: Nice gameplay. Good graphics. Awesome sensations, and neat twists. It's a tad bit short, bit is exceptionally grand.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Portal is 2007 First-person puzzle game developed by Valve in which you take the role of the main protagonist, Chell, as she tries to escape from Aperture Science Labs.In this game, you, eventually, get the hold of the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device aka Portal gun, which, obviously is used for creating portals. Levels are designed in a way that you have to think where to shoot the portals and get harder as the game progresses on. Further on, you will have to deal with turrets and think of clever ways to do that. Portals cannot be created on certain surfaces. Portal's level design is brilliant and players will have to use the environment to their advantage. Story is also pretty good, and there is more of it in the second game. Last thing, there is cake.The only downside I can think of is that its pretty short and can be completed in less than 3 hours, but I definitely recommend this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Words cannot describe what I feel for Portal, but since this is is a review I kind of have to so here goes.When I first bought Portal it was the first time I had ever played a game where I was clueless as to what it's main goal was. It got me asking multiple questins: Who was I? Was there a villain? If so what was their intention?Due to my unawareness throughout playing it gave me a slight nervousness and jitteryness within certain chambers.It's atmosphere is unlike any other game I have ever played. I recommend this game to be played with headphones at a moderatley high volume where every footstep and movement can be heard. There were points throughout the game where I genuinly felt alone and disconected from the outside world (but if you're a skyrim or Wow player you already know that feel). This was all due to the games lack of contact that you have with the games narrator who is guiding you throughout the tests. Because of the on and off again dialogue you really get to be alone with your thoughts and it creates a more chilling design whenever you hear the voice of GLaDoS in levels.The gameplay itself was not dissapointing so much as thought provoking, in some first-person games such as CoD your objective is simple; KILL EVERYTHING. In Portal you can sometimes spend a while thinking what your objective is and how to solve the puzzle (however frustrating it may have become)The challenges can become somewhat tedious at points  but that differs from gamer to gamer.If you want an hour or two to kill I recommend this gameIf you want a twenty plus hour game experience I wouldn't steer clear from it but I would prepare myself for what may seem as a quick game.9.5/10Pros:-Brilliant Gameplay and Design-Excellent atmosphereCons:-Challenges can become tedious-Urge to buy Portal 2 even though I am brokeSuper Pro:-End credit song

content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Portal, at it's core, is a great game for those who seek innovative gameplay, intriguing puzzles and a "Story line" of which has never been approached before.Although short, Portal is not greatly story orientated, nor is it multiplayer or co-op whatsoever, but it still provides the same entertainment you would expect for a first-person puzzle game (because there are sooooo many of those).In nearly any First Person game you will find a puzzle/maze like section that does not feel as it belongs in the game, but in Portal the tables are turned. Portal has a nice balance between gore, blood and... wait wait, nope wrong review. Portal has a nice balance between puzzling areas and a first person aspect that has been used many times, but with Portal everything just feels...right.In conclusion I definitely recommend Portal for those who have a brain, those who don't, well, you can either see a doctor or buy portal (2nd choice recommended)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Game: PortalSummary: Quirky, inventive first-person puzzle game with a good ending.Rating (5/10 = failure): 9/10Multiplayer: NoCompletion: 5 hrsCards: NoCloud: YesCost: 2.5 USDRefreshingly, for a first person game, Portal is not a shooter in the traditional sense. The name of the game is to escape, using a fascinating device that lets you open up personal wormholes on special surfaces. Guiding you on your way is a forever omnipresent computer AI that is perhaps a little too interested in testing her subjects.I take that back. The name of the game is to drop yourself into infinite free fall, hurl yourself across giant chasms of acid, and somehow always land like a cat. And damn is that fun.Puzzles, for the most part, involve moving blocks onto platforms so that you can open a door. But thankfully that's not nearly as boring as it sounds. You'll have to get creative, and, while it bothers me when puzzle games do this, you'll need to bring reflexes/timing into some puzzles.My only problem (which is a personal problem) is that the game is entirely in first person. I can't play for too long without suffering from motion sickness. I would have liked it if the game allowed 3rd person without the use of the console. I understand they wanted to keep the player's identity a secret until you look at yourself through a portal, but it's not like this was a major reveal or anything. This is enough of a problem for me that I had to dock some points for the game because I still fail to see how 3rd person would have ruined the experience.Very well thought-out puzzles, good narrative, and a great ending song (which I didn't really connect with until I played the game) that will stick in your head for weeks. 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												(my old Portal review from dawnbreakergaming.com)Portal to the PastFor the approximate 5 people in the world who haven’t heard about this game, on October 10th, 2007, Valve released this little game named Portal, as part of a package known as The Orange Box. Published and developed by Valve Corporation, it was released on Valve’s own digital store, Steam, and it was also available for the XBox 360 and the PlayStation 3. Originally, I only wanted the Orange Box for the game Team Fortress 2, a game I had been eagerly awaiting the release of for years, as I played the original mod for the game Quake. However, since Portal came with it, I decided to give it a shot. Once I started playing, I ended up staying up all night and completing the game. Portal is by no means a very long game, but it lasted long enough to be a very enjoyable experience without overstaying its welcome. PlotPortal revolves around the player character protagonist Chell, who wakes up from stasis to warnings and instructions for the upcoming tests in what is called the Enrichment Center. Chell then proceeds through these test chambers, which get increasingly dangerous. Despite promises of counseling (and cake) from the AI known as GLaDOS, it becomes clear GLaDOS does not regard human life as very valuable. As the story progresses you obtain the use of a Portal gun, which allows you to project 2 portals on to various surfaces.  Each portal created can be used as an entrance, and after entering either one, you’ll then exit at the location of the other portal.  This allows you to travel instantaneously between them, but you also keep your momentum as you pass through them, allowing you to do a variety of physics tricks that can help you reach various locations.Now it is hard to really go into the plot without spoiling things, so without ruining the surprise, the plot revolves around your fight for survival as you travel through the world alone. The game provides you with mostly inanimate objects and verbal abuse from the aforementioned GLaDOS.  Humans are reduced to guinea pigs as GLaDOS pits you against various rooms that force you to solve puzzles on how to reach certain locations, as well as a variety of other challenges,  such as moving objects around to hold down buttons, all while trying to stay alive.  There are many dangers that you’ll encounter, and they can be as simple as avoiding a deadly liquid, to dodging military droids that track and shoot you when moving within their view.  Somehow, through all of these fairly empty chambers, you will find the most compelling of stories. By design, you will get attached to the most unlikely of companions. “Somehow, through all of these fairly empty chambers, you will find the most compelling of stories.” GameplayPortal is a mix of first person shooter and puzzle-platformer, and in my opinion, it is probably one of the best games ever to mix those genres. Instead of shooting things to kill or destroy them outright, you use your Portal gun to navigate a series of test chambers by moving between locations you would not be able to reach by normal means, as well as move objects that can be the key to opening the path to exiting these chambers. Luckily you are equipped in such a way that keeps you from taking any fall damage, or else each chamber would be even more dangerous and deadlier than they already are. There is often more than one way of using your portal gun and items in your surroundings to reach your goals. In fact there are additional challenges in the game, separate from the main story line, that pit you against a time clock, or have you complete specific chambers with the least amount of portal use as possible. After the main story I wanted to play Portal so much more that I went back and played through these challenges as well.  I was surprised that I was able to complete a deceptively vast chamber with literally 2 portals. I'm even fairly certain that I completed a test chamber in the most unique of ways; using a wall that opens temporarily by placing the exit portal on it while it was open. In short, the gameplay is wonderful, with the use of tight controls, physics, and a bit of creativity, the things you can do are amazing. Being able to think through a puzzle and execute the motions required to finish the chamber results in the most satisfying feeling! “Being able to think through a puzzle and execute the motions required to finish the chamber results in the most satisfying feeling!”EnvironmentsThe test chambers feature a very clean aesthetic that starts out simple, but become more complex over time. It seems clear that the chambers were designed not only to convey the situation you were in, but also to allow the player to easily gauge their portal shots to effectively navigate each puzzle presented. They have a mix of artistic style and practicality that I wish more games effectively accomplished. Various things are added to the simple world as you progress, but hidden around the corner from the sleek walls that you see are things that break up the otherwise very similar surroundings of each test chamber. As you progress, and perchance get tired of the solid colors and shapes of many locals, the game changes the surroundings, dramatically keeping you engaged in what is a fairly linear path. The aesthetic is so well liked that it has been copied in many other places, such as a map in the game Killing Floor. I personally enjoy it a lot and seek to play other games that have levels inspired by Portal. Most of the game has a non-lyrical, ambient music that is made to match the mood of the environments, and in the ending credits there is a song called “Still Alive” which many adore. The song’s execution and humor is hard to adequately describe, but I can say that it has been praised and played in various places. (source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Still_Alive) More InfoPortal is a spiritual successor to the freeware game Narbacular Drop, which was a 2005 independent indie game developed by Nuclear Monkey Software. Robin Walker, one of Valve’s developers, saw the game at the DigiPen Institute of Technology annual career fair, which then lead to Gabe Newell, CEO of Valve, seeing the game and offering the entire team jobs at Valve. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal_(video_game) and

 )The Portal universe is actually set in the Half-Life universe, another game created by Valve. There is also an official comic called Lab Rat that connects the story of the original Portal, to its sequel, Portal 2. Portal is now also available to enjoy on OS X, Linux, and Android. The game’s popularity has lead to a wide variety of merchandise associated with Portal, such as coffee mugs and plush toys. There is also an on going internet meme relating to the phrase “the cake is a lie.” PerformanceFrom my perspective of the PC version; the game runs very well, as it should on fairly modern systems due to the fact it is built on Valve’s Source Engine, which has been used in many games such as Counter Strike: Source, Left 4 Dead, and Half-Life 2.  It does not even require a gig of RAM or a multi-core processor, so even older PC’s or laptops can easily play this game. (source:  ) Bottom LineI love this game, and I’m certainly not alone, as many, many, many others also love it. In fact, it received critical reception, as it earned more praise than Half-Life 2: Episode Two, and Team Fortress 2, which were both included in the Orange Box. It won various awards including Game of the Year, Innovation Award, and Best Game Design at the 2008 Game Developers Choice Awards. (source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal_(video_game) http://www.gamechoiceawards.com/archive/gdca_8th.html) Great story. Great humor. Great puzzles. If you like FPS with a side of puzzles and dark humor, this game is for you!

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												I'm racking my brain, trying to think of a reason to say this game isn't perfect that doesn't seem like a petty nitpick.I reject the ideas of length (a choice) and replayability (unavoidable in the genre).  The one-note nature of the puzzles has some merit, but the whole game is about the portals, so that's not it.  The FPS controls will prove a barrier to non-gamers, limiting accessibility, but, again, this springs from a selection of engine that I don't think is wrong.  A couple of the puzzles were a little obtuse, but once you figured them out, they made sense, and anyway, you wouldn't want it to be too easy.  The main reason I don't like physics puzzlers is that their engine is too sensitive or finicky, and even once you figure out the solution, it takes a frustrating number of repetitions to implement it.  This never bothered me in Portal, though (probably because you're not stacking things, it's always just one box and some portals).  Timed sections are a little annoying, and the final boss a tad out-of-place, but that's really minor.  The idea that everyone else thinks it's great, so I should disagree is just childish.Nope, it's perfect (or as close as a game can get).

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I was thinking one day, if I was going to introduce one game to someone who has never played a game or had any interest in gaming. I thought about this long and hard. Would it be an old game to show them how it started? Should it be a recent game to show them where were are now? Console or PC, Story driven or arcade-y, and what genre? I thought about this long and hard. Then it hit me. Portal. It starts off slow, but not too slow. It give the player a mystery, letting them be intrigued and keep on going. It doesn't rush them into anything, so it's not overwhelming. The gamplay is unique, and anyone would be interested in the concept of using portals to solve puzzles. The puzzles are designed in such way that they are challenging for anyone, yet you don't need any outside knowledge to solve them. It's not overly anything, there would be no way a new player would get overwhelmed and want to quit. Yet the game drives you to move forward. It's briliant. I don't think any game is perfect. But the closest game to being perfect would have to be Portal. So yeah, buy it and stuff.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												(my old Portal review from dawnbreakergaming.com)Portal to the PastFor the approximate 5 people in the world who haven’t heard about this game, on October 10th, 2007, Valve released this little game named Portal, as part of a package known as The Orange Box. Published and developed by Valve Corporation, it was released on Valve’s own digital store, Steam, and it was also available for the XBox 360 and the PlayStation 3. Originally, I only wanted the Orange Box for the game Team Fortress 2, a game I had been eagerly awaiting the release of for years, as I played the original mod for the game Quake. However, since Portal came with it, I decided to give it a shot. Once I started playing, I ended up staying up all night and completing the game. Portal is by no means a very long game, but it lasted long enough to be a very enjoyable experience without overstaying its welcome. PlotPortal revolves around the player character protagonist Chell, who wakes up from stasis to warnings and instructions for the upcoming tests in what is called the Enrichment Center. Chell then proceeds through these test chambers, which get increasingly dangerous. Despite promises of counseling (and cake) from the AI known as GLaDOS, it becomes clear GLaDOS does not regard human life as very valuable. As the story progresses you obtain the use of a Portal gun, which allows you to project 2 portals on to various surfaces.  Each portal created can be used as an entrance, and after entering either one, you’ll then exit at the location of the other portal.  This allows you to travel instantaneously between them, but you also keep your momentum as you pass through them, allowing you to do a variety of physics tricks that can help you reach various locations.Now it is hard to really go into the plot without spoiling things, so without ruining the surprise, the plot revolves around your fight for survival as you travel through the world alone. The game provides you with mostly inanimate objects and verbal abuse from the aforementioned GLaDOS.  Humans are reduced to guinea pigs as GLaDOS pits you against various rooms that force you to solve puzzles on how to reach certain locations, as well as a variety of other challenges,  such as moving objects around to hold down buttons, all while trying to stay alive.  There are many dangers that you’ll encounter, and they can be as simple as avoiding a deadly liquid, to dodging military droids that track and shoot you when moving within their view.  Somehow, through all of these fairly empty chambers, you will find the most compelling of stories. By design, you will get attached to the most unlikely of companions. “Somehow, through all of these fairly empty chambers, you will find the most compelling of stories.” GameplayPortal is a mix of first person shooter and puzzle-platformer, and in my opinion, it is probably one of the best games ever to mix those genres. Instead of shooting things to kill or destroy them outright, you use your Portal gun to navigate a series of test chambers by moving between locations you would not be able to reach by normal means, as well as move objects that can be the key to opening the path to exiting these chambers. Luckily you are equipped in such a way that keeps you from taking any fall damage, or else each chamber would be even more dangerous and deadlier than they already are. There is often more than one way of using your portal gun and items in your surroundings to reach your goals. In fact there are additional challenges in the game, separate from the main story line, that pit you against a time clock, or have you complete specific chambers with the least amount of portal use as possible. After the main story I wanted to play Portal so much more that I went back and played through these challenges as well.  I was surprised that I was able to complete a deceptively vast chamber with literally 2 portals. I'm even fairly certain that I completed a test chamber in the most unique of ways; using a wall that opens temporarily by placing the exit portal on it while it was open. In short, the gameplay is wonderful, with the use of tight controls, physics, and a bit of creativity, the things you can do are amazing. Being able to think through a puzzle and execute the motions required to finish the chamber results in the most satisfying feeling! “Being able to think through a puzzle and execute the motions required to finish the chamber results in the most satisfying feeling!”EnvironmentsThe test chambers feature a very clean aesthetic that starts out simple, but become more complex over time. It seems clear that the chambers were designed not only to convey the situation you were in, but also to allow the player to easily gauge their portal shots to effectively navigate each puzzle presented. They have a mix of artistic style and practicality that I wish more games effectively accomplished. Various things are added to the simple world as you progress, but hidden around the corner from the sleek walls that you see are things that break up the otherwise very similar surroundings of each test chamber. As you progress, and perchance get tired of the solid colors and shapes of many locals, the game changes the surroundings, dramatically keeping you engaged in what is a fairly linear path. The aesthetic is so well liked that it has been copied in many other places, such as a map in the game Killing Floor. I personally enjoy it a lot and seek to play other games that have levels inspired by Portal. Most of the game has a non-lyrical, ambient music that is made to match the mood of the environments, and in the ending credits there is a song called “Still Alive” which many adore. The song’s execution and humor is hard to adequately describe, but I can say that it has been praised and played in various places. (source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Still_Alive) More InfoPortal is a spiritual successor to the freeware game Narbacular Drop, which was a 2005 independent indie game developed by Nuclear Monkey Software. Robin Walker, one of Valve’s developers, saw the game at the DigiPen Institute of Technology annual career fair, which then lead to Gabe Newell, CEO of Valve, seeing the game and offering the entire team jobs at Valve. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal_(video_game) and

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Portal is one of the best... kinda first-person shooter games out there, without actually shooting any bullets. (Is it a fps? Well, that´s debatable.) The game most certainly is a puzzle game, so your gonna have to use your brain on this one. Portal is a game that will challenge your MIND. So unlike in most games, you have to actually think while playing this... and think ALOT. This kinda challenge can be very tricky in a video game and can easily ruin the gameplay, but the Portal does just the opposite: The gameplay is fun because it´s challenging! The game is just enough difficult to be competitive in a good way, the feeling you get when clearing a difficult level without any help is super rewarding experience! Add this with GlaDOS and a portal gun (which is, let´s be real here: one of the coolest "weapon" in a world of gaming) and you have a super joyful, challenging and unique game, that is an absolute must-have jewel in your library.4/5 This game has the best credits i have ever seen

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Something about cake and cupcakes or whatever. The cake meme might be the Internet equivalent of a Roman fresco, but this game will forever remain a timeless classic.Portal is a short but sweet first person puzzle game, with great writing, intelligent pacing, and a truly sublime main mechanic that was all the more stunning when it first came out in 2007. It was also one of the 5 titles in the Orange Box collection, which was my personal introduction to Valve games. And it's still good.Advanced levels and level challenges are available once you've finished the main story. There is also rudimentary custom level support (no Steam Workshop here) with plenty of custom levels to be found on the internet.No multiplayer though, and nothing like the gels, lasers and light bridges from Portal 2 - but maybe we don't need those here.Buy this if you like good games and gaming history.

content:
Posted: January 27
												Portal is a game that takes a mechanic that has been an interesting concept in video games for a long time and puts some new twists on it. Portal is slow at first when introducing the game and the mechanics, but makes you feel like a wizard at puzzles later in the game. Tactics and intentional exploits make the game sometimes not only have one way to solve a certain puzzle. One thing that I was disappointed with at first was how short the actual main gameplay is. But with other things like the Advanced and Challenge maps, and also the importable bonus maps. The gameplay becomes so much better to give the extra challenge to players that were bored with the original gameplay. This overall makes Portal a great game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Portal is a surprise hit. It ended up becoming one of Valve's best games. It's immediately fresh, and is easy to pick up but hard to master. It's such a great game, and is a must own for any PC gamer!Positives- Fresh and original gameplay that uses portals- Surprisingly interesting backstory and characters for such a short story- Good amount of post-story content like challange mode and advanced chambers, which are much harder versions of the story chambers.Negatives- Story is pretty short. I was able to complete it in an hour, but that was because I've beaten the game on 360 twice so I memorized the chambers.SummaryPortal is a bittersweet game. It's short, but so great. It fits in the term "quality over quantity." I can easily recommend it!Should you buy it? YES! I recommend buying the Portal bundle that includes Portal 1 and 2, as both games are amazing.My review on Portal 2

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												"Come back to the recovery annex,for your cake"-GLaDOSAfter beating Portal 2(which is also an amazing game btw :) ),I got this game during the summer sale,and recently tried the game out,and I agree with other people who have played this game on the fact that it is an amazing game,despite it's short lengthThe plot(in a basic summary,I'm not entirely sure of plot details myself): You play as a woman named Chell who,under the"supervision"(sort of xD)of the AI GLaDOS,go through 19 test chambers,using a portal gun that creates orange and blue portals,which really play a key role in solving puzzles in the test chambers. Eventually you turn against GLaDOS,discovering GLaDOS's true plans,and destroy her once and for all(except until Portal 2 of course)The music is very good,in fact,in the relaxation vault at the beginning of the game,there's a nice little catchy song that plays on a radio :) While there are kinda few characters in this game(really there's only GLaDOS,Chell,and the turrets,and that's it)they still are very likable characters,especially GLaDOS with her hilarious dialogue(R.I.P. youtube comments section with their"THE CAKE IS A LIE"spam XD)The puzzles aren't as complex I would say as Portal 2's puzzles are,but they still are kinda challenging,in fact some involve timing putting your Portals on portal-able surfaces rightOverall,while this game is pretty short(It should take you about 2-4 hours your first time),the hilarious dialogue,nice learning curve on the puzzles for those new to Portal,and great characters make up for that10/10 from me :)

												This game was the first game that started my experience on Steam. For those who aren't used to the "AWSD" controller on keyboard, this is a good start. Pretty much a Puzzle/Action type game where you place certain "Portals" and must make the right movements in order to get it right. It may seem boring at first, but the story and revelation of "Aperture Science" evolves, and even the challenges increase. A good game that can get you addicted easily...or a game just to past the time.^_^

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Portal is one of those games that gets you thinking. The game indirectly teaches you new strategies to solve the puzzles, and it feels rewarding when you realize how to solve them. After solving a series of puzzles you are then awarded with cake.I was instantly hooked by the smart concept of this game. Portal comes with great mechanics and style. The levels pace very well; they start off easy and are quick while the later levels become more challenging. Although it can be quite frustrating at times, frustrating enough to the point where you are stuck and must see a walkthrough online, the puzzles are generally easy and you can finish the game in 4 hours or less. Because you will only get a few hours from this game, I would recommend to wait on that discount or go for The Orange Box (bundle). Either way you will not regret buying Portal and have immense fun playing the few hours it serves!93/100

												Portal is a game that takes a mechanic that has been an interesting concept in video games for a long time and puts some new twists on it. Portal is slow at first when introducing the game and the mechanics, but makes you feel like a wizard at puzzles later in the game. Tactics and intentional exploits make the game sometimes not only have one way to solve a certain puzzle. One thing that I was disappointed with at first was how short the actual main gameplay is. But with other things like the Advanced and Challenge maps, and also the importable bonus maps. The gameplay becomes so much better to give the extra challenge to players that were bored with the original gameplay. This overall makes Portal a great game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Portal is definitely not the best game I ever played, but I had some fun playing it. An idea to use portal mechanic to create puzzles absolutely got me. I understand that it's a rather old game for today's standards, but I'd like to point some flaws of it. Firstly, it's rather short. Completing the main story took me around 2 hours. Not much comparing with other games. Don't expect a long journey from it, but on the other side, it's the time well spent.Secondly (that's gonna be a good one) - the puzzles were rather easy. I'm not telling it was a cakewalk (oops, that was an accident, I promise), but this game lacks real challenge aside from 6 advanced test chambers. That's only my opinion, though, I'd really appreciate to hear yours.But there is also a thing I'd like to mention too - there are actually very few loading screens. Not like it has a crucial meaning, but it really makes you not die waiting.Overall, I do not regret playing this game. Of course, every game has it flaws, but hey - nothing's perfect. Considering Portal's pros and cons, I can give it solid 7.5/10. See that game on sale? Buy it. Try it out....Graphics? What the hell do you want from graphics? They're good, just enjoy the game itself.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												The cake may be a lie, but the fun isn't.Portal uses a very unique gameplay that wasn't seen in the other Valve games. The only "weapon" you're given is a portal gun that can shoot a portal entrance with the right mouse button and a portal exit with the left mouse button. Once both portals have been placed, you can walk though them. The portals can be shot across a distance but only on certain surfaces, which creates the puzzle atmosphere. You'll have to figure out how to get across chasms, up and over obstacles, and around automated turrets. The trick is that you can only have one entrance and one exit meaning you'll encounter many brain teasers on how to use the portals correctly and in some cases, quickly and often. It'll make you think about which portal you're placing, the exact location of where it needs to go, and the timing of when portals need to be switched.You're not the only thing that can move through these portals. The weighted companion blocks can be used to take out turrets by placing a portal over the turret's head and another under a block. Energy spheres are used frequently where players have to negotiate their path using portals to activate a switch. There are some really fun uses of the portals here, especially in all of those strange moments where you can see yourself through a portal across the room entering the portal you're stepping through.While the main game is short, Portal doesn't only finish with one of the best credits songs ever created. After the story is done new challenge levels are unlocked. These extras are six levels that you've already played. The difference is that they have new challenges associated with them. You'll have to see if you can complete the puzzles in a certain amount of time, a minimum number of footsteps, or using only a certain number of portals. These challenges are really interesting because they make you consider puzzles that were somewhat simple to figure out in a different way. The idea behind Portal ends up being more brilliant than Portal itself.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
-Quick Review-Portal is a First-Person Puzzle game developed by Valve and released late 2007. Portal is completely dedicated to solving problems by using two portals to move objects or the protagonist through the various puzzles.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: Portal takes place exclusively in the Apature Science Laboratories Enrichment Center. The Silent Protagonist Bby the name of “Chell”) awakens in a small room, she is instructed by the Artificial Intelligence known as “GlaDOS” to complete the various test chambers and then Chell will be rewarded with cake.


First objects you see - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Portal
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: The gameplay introduced by Portal was probably one of the most innovative and unique concepts introduced by valve, and easily one of the best games released in 2007.As you progress through the game, you are introduced slowly to new concepts and new tricks that you can implement. You start the game with the extremely primitive concept of “put the block on the button”, but after completing a sequence of Test Chambers and obtaining the “Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device” or just “portal gun”, the puzzles get really crazy.Achievements: There are 15 achievements in Portal, five achievements are normally unlocked on your first play through, another five achievements are very well explained and relatively easy to obtain (Generally by knowing the best location to get them, or preforming specific tricks, or completing some advanced maps).The last set of achievements is the toughest, earning gold medals on all portal challenges, Detaching all security cameras from the walls, and Finding all the hidden Transmissions. (Unless you're going to put an ungodly amount of time into portal, you'll probably need to read guides.)


Test chamber 08 - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Portal
By: Atratzu




Price: Portal is priced at $9.99, the value system I use is “Price divided by GameTime = Value”. Generally playing through the Portal story once will be about 6 hours, give or take a few hours depending on puzzle solving skill. This game has enough content to keep the player busy for 9 hours, but most people won't take advantage of all the features, so the price is a bit high. I suggest going for a bundle deal like the Orange Box (Especially if you're interested in the Half-Life 2 games), or waiting for a steam sale before purchasing.Conclusion: Story: Excellent, some of the finest content Valve has ever released. Gameplay: Memorable, enjoyable, and addicting. Achievements: a nice blend of difficulty, but not an easy 100% completion game. Price: A bit higher then what I'd prefer, but on the enjoyable factor, Portal is definitely worth it.I have a personal bias for this game, because the first product I bought on Steam was the Orange Box, so this is among the first games I've ever played on Steam! I easily recommend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzle games, but this game can appeal to just about anyone, hardcore and softcore alike.

content:
Posted: March 25
 Overview Portal is, although short, a really fun game. It's puzzles are not too complicated and are more of a  tutorial  of the game then, really, a part of the game. It doesn't have too good of an aesthetics, as the textures repeat a lot. In the beginning, you are pretty much clueless about the story, it's mostly told when you are nearing to the end of the game. Playtime Portal's playtime is about 2.5-3 hours. If you want to 100% the game (get all the achievements, etc.) it will take about 7-8 hours. Rating   Aspect Rating Description   Story 5/10 The story isn't told very well.  You have to explore the chambers a bit to get small pieces of the story that are       written on the walls. The most of the story is told to the player when the game is nearing the end.   Aesthetics 7/10 The textures on the rooms get a little bit repetitive. All the textures repeat in every test chamber. The only part where you see a bit of change is when the game is nearing it's end.   Mechanics 9/10 Portal mechanics work really well, even though there are a few bugs, it's pretty good. Running and jumping do feel a bit slow, but every modern game does that nowadays.   Graphics 7/10 Portal is a realatively old game. So the graphics aren't that great, but it isn't like that they are bad either.   Overall rating 7/10

Posted: April 30, 2014
												Great game! It is pretty easy, and the flexibility of the solutions to each level makes the timed challenge mode more complex. Also, the "Transmission Recieved" achievement makes it more challenging for the overachievers. I have most of the radios, but I still have a headache or two to defeat still. The advanced test chambers demand better planning, timing, and nerve, and are relatively challenging... until you beat the first couple of levels. From there on, it gets easy until level 18, which puzzled me for a while on the first time playing through on the NORMAL version. The game is not very long. I wish it was longer. It needs to introduce the turrets earlier, if you ask me. If not, it needs to have more turrets and it needs to make removing them more challenging. Even the upgraded version of the turret seems almost harmless if you have a good rame rate. Even the final boss fight was simple and easy to defeat. I do not think difficulty was the point of this game. I think the main point of it was to just introduce players to the idea, concept, story, and format of the Portal series. All of these four things are artfully designed and are quite entertaining. I think the point of this game is to prepare players for the sequel, Portal 2. I have not played the sequel, so I do not know that for sure. If you're looking for just a fun and quick puzzle game that is relatively easy to master, then this is the game for you. If you are looking for more action in your gameplay, this may not be the game for you. I am one of those people, but I still enjoyed, enjoy, and will enjoy this game for a very long time. I think everyone can and should do the same, if they have the right mindset.

												First, before I got this game on PC I played through it twice on Xbox. It is an amazing piece of gaming idealism(that works!). THe beautifly simple yet complex rooms that are embelished with the idea of the portal gun that creates worm holes to travel from place to place in an instant! It's revolutionary and I'm betting that the same kind of computational math will be what future games use for doorway room instance travel for easy transition to another place in games. But really, a pscyho computer out to get you while you jump through hoops(figurative and literal). I think this game deserves an award, oh it has some! Almost all games that get a sequel are worth playing, and this one is at the top of the list, it gets a sequel, and although it looks like the series ended I hope there is another one. A prequel sequel or something! I rate this game a 10/10. Well done creators!

Posted: April 16, 2014
												Portal is one of those games you just would not have the heart to delete from your computer or library. The game carries the sense of wanting to replay and think to new ways to try and solve the already beaten puzzles but the only real con to this game is that it IS short, but you can find yourself lost for what seems like hours on end when doing some of the puzzles which is not a bad thing at all. If you find it over youtube or seen your friend play it, the real experience is in playing it yourself. While it is possible to play PORTAL 2 without playing the original, you really don't get the sense of "Hey I seen this before!" or "Oh I remember this trick I did back in one puzzle" Yes there would be times you would find yourself lost and confuse on a puzzle, I would only suggest looking for playthroughs on youtube as a real last resort, I have done this for one puzzle and it did lose abet of magic for me playing a new game the first time, but it was still awesome to play first hand.

There are many aspects of this game that I liked and few that i didnt like about the game.I'll start off listing the positives: + Gameplay is stunning, I had a lot of fun finishing this game.+ Puzzles were tricky and kept game fresh.+ Story was good but was short.+ Sounded good, i loved the computer voices.+ Graphics were nothing amazing but aged well.Here are some negatives that come to mind:- Very short game, left me dissapointed that it was over so quickly.- Not too much replayability after finishing the story.- Play Portal 2 for a much better overall expierence Overall this is a great game and I fo sho recommend it to anyone.My Rating: ★★★★☆

Posted: December 21, 2013
												Valve always seem to think outside the box for FPS's. Portal is a prime example of that. Thrust into a indoor testing facility setting, you begin the game waiting and wondering what to do. The moment the first ever blue portal appears, you KNOW it's going to be a unique experience, which it certainly is. Playing with the mechanics of the portals is a seriously original concept and a breath of fresh air in gaming, not to mention that playing with momentum and physics can be really good fun and put to good use, particularly in the later stages of the game. When people talk about Portal, they'll probably talk about GlaDos, the AI character that guides you and how entertaining she is. Sure, she has her funny lines but she never really seemed as good as what I'd heard about her. Also, this game is pretty short to be honest. It's easy to beat it in a day and the challenges on the side don't extend it too much unless you're a die-hard completionist, in my opinion. However, if you look past the length, Portal is a great game to keep your attention for a while and has some genuinely great moments and gameplay. If you're not interested in the challenges, pick it up during a sale. If you're more of a completionist, pick it up at any time you want. 8/10 (Great)

Posted: September 28, 2013
The GoodPretty much everything.For serious.  The music is catchy as hell, and I found myself singing "Still Alive" . . . well, actually, I'm not certain I've ever stopped.  The setting is a wonderful mixture of sterile and creepy before breaking apart and becoming grungy industrial and creepy, which works very well.  The story, while fairly basic, is handled expertly through the amazing characterization of GLaDOS.  The puzzles are amazingly fun to figure out as they tend to involve flinging stuff (including yourself) here and there and everywhere else.  And even if there weren't puzzles to figure out, the portal gun itself is insanely fun to fiddle around with.  You could spend hours in the game doing nothing but trying out all the cool stuff you can do with it.The BadUm.  Hmm.  I would say it's too short, but honestly I felt I got more out of three hours of gameplay from Portal than I've gotten out of a lot longer times spent on some other games.  And there's always more Portal to be had in the form of Portal 2.About the only downside I can really think of has nothing to do with the game, in fact.  It's really just that so much of it had been spoiled for me before I ever even got to play it.  For at least a few weeks after it came out, it seemed like it was the only thing anyone was talking about.  But even then, when those moments that had been spoiled popped up while I was playing, they not only didn't feel any worse off for my having known about them beforehand, they simply shone all the more for now having all the proper context to enjoy them in.OverallNot the best game I've ever played ever, but by gum, it's way up there.

Posted: March 28, 2016
												Portal was a triumph, or was it? Time to see if this cake is also a lie.So just to start off I originally played portal about 5 years ago and I thought it was amazing. So I have nostalgia for this game, fair warning before you assume this review is unbiased. Portal is a game that revolutionized the puzzle platformer genre, with its new and unheard of, space bending mechanics. But I find that its story is pretty average. The humor is on point, but really all we know throughout the game is that we are in some sort of testing facility where everyone died and a supercomputer known as the GLaDOS (genetic life form and disc operating system). Even at the end of the game, our victory seems hollow as a robot drags us back in, but those brief moments of sunlight are memorable. In the end it’s the clever humor, and light themes about freedom that make portal's narrative matter. But that doesn't exactly mean there IS much story, some test chambers and silent and the environment (normally) doesn't really give much more then setting a mood. The game hints at some other person living throughout the halls of Aperture in some of its secrets and collectables, but it leaves more questions than answers. In the end the story feels like a test and a set up for a sequel, which is exactly what it ended up being. (*portal 2*).Portal's presentation is actually pretty good. The lack of color in the walls makes the environment seem sterile and like a laboratory, and the maintenance tunnels are shaded in a red light to add to the danger and scale of the environment. Each use of color has purpose that tells the plays how to interact with the environment. For instance the red light of the turret means get the ♥♥♥♥ away. Graphically the game still hold up today and has aged pretty well. It’s quite impressive given that the game was a mod of half life 2. Seriously: I have no complaints about the way this game looks. Mechanically however it's clear that Portal 1 was a test. The portal mechanic, while smart and innovative, glitches out constantly. You can shoot portals through portals, push portals through walls, actually glitch out of the environment with the portal gun, etc. And that doesn't mention the other glitches. Objects will disappear spontaneously on occasion and you'll have to reboot the game to fix it. But in spite of these flaws the game play is still the most memorable part of this game. Manipulating space is really enjoyable and the other challenges like turrets, energy balls, moving platforms, and cubes are all simple but have their own personality and come across as very well implemented. In short, the game play is clever but in need of major refinement, The sound of Portal 1 is in some ways great and in others, completely unremarkable. Sound effects of turrets talking, GLaDOS's voiceovers, portals launching, doors opening sound fresh and vibrant,. They can even make you laugh simply with a well designed sound effect. However the OST is completely unremarkable. Every track, while feeling sterile and empty like the environment, is really just not memorable. I simply remember all the test chambers as silent. There is one exception of course: Still Alive. Still Alive is one of the greatest songs in gaming history; a hidden gem among a pile of broken turrets.So to summarize:PROS:- Good mechanics- Clever level design- Personality/creativity- Working story (no plot holes)- Thematically fantastic Presentation- Graphics aged well- Still AliveCONS:- Unremarkable OST- So much glitch- Story begs for a sequal- Still feels like a mod"But Damself", you say, "I'm a completionist, should I..." no. no. no. no. no. no. First of all In order to complete this game you have to jump through a lot of literal hoops. Completing the story is a good start, but then you need to go back and detach all the cameras from the walls and collect all of the radios and move them around the map till they start chirping with sound that can be decoded into images. That part really isn't that unreasonable and honestly is still pretty fun as an additional puzzle component. Next there are the advanced maps, which take the maps you've already played once and turn them on their head by putting acid on the floor or something. These are also pretty easy, and challenging, and fun. They are a great addition to the game for people who want a little more challenge without feeling like they're wasting their time. The Challenge maps however are horrible. They are difficult as hell and often require you to use the game's glitches or mechanics that the game was not even designed to have in order to beat them. The worst are the least steps challenges, because Chell slides a little when she walks, so you'll be tearing your hair out when you get 51 steps and the goal is at 49. Worse than that is the fact that there is no completion bonus, so all your hours (and I mean HOURS) of trying to beat the challenge maps with glitches and poorly designed box throwing mechanics, net you nothing. In the end I'd give Portal a solid 7.3/10 and a completionist rating of FINISH IT!

Posted: December 20, 2015
												Portal is a  very simple but yet advanced game. It is probably the best puzzle game i have ever played with an amazing story filled with hard to solve puzzles. Buying portal today is going to give you around 4-5 hours of main story puzzels and probably another 5-10 hours of co-op gameplay and custom maps made by players. Portal is probably not the longest game ever, but it is for sure one of my top enjoyable ''mini-games'' out there. I will forever remember some of the items and characters in this game. Portal is worth every single dollar i paid. I recommend this game so highly. overall rating - 9/10Portal <3

Posted: May 15, 2015
												DISCLAIMER: i've played mostly on xbox 360 back when it was released around 2007-08. I got the game for free a couple years back on steam and I only recently replayed it on PC. Portal(both games) are the best 3d puzzlers i've ever played in my life. The game is challenging, has a great story-line (mostly the 2nd one) and has this oppressing feeling all the way through that makes it all the more interesting. The main attribute of the first Portal is the gameplay (the 2nd game keeps that and adds in a great story.) The game is fluid, it will make you think inside and outside the box in every way possible and the humor is very nice at times.I would recommend this to anybody who is looking for a unique gaming experience with high production quality, even if you don't think you would enjoy the puzzles at first. I would also recommend getting both Portal games because you would be missing out if you only got one of them.

Posted: September 13, 2011
												Wow, just wow. For a title that’s only two hours long (give or take), Portal is an exemplary game that keeps drawing you back to play it through again and again. The simple and yet brilliant premise of portal-based puzzle solving plus a simple and yet brilliantly well told story dripping with black comedy is an odd combo that somehow works to turn this game into a modern masterpiece, one of the first for the gaming world. A must have for everybody, not just gamers. This game not only is fun, but it also tests your mind, something that even parents can get into. Dive on in, and get ready for a portal-hopping good time!

Posted: June 23, 2014
												I beat this game in 4.3 hours. It was one of the best 4.3 hours I've ever spent. This game is a great puzzle game. The music, story, gameplay mechanics, and general quality all shine and make the short playthrough acceptable in my eyes. This is a game anyone on Steam should play at some point. If not for it being developed by Valve, then for it simply being a great all around game. Enjoy it, because it's over quick (depending on your skill).

												After hearing about the cake being a lie all these years I never actually knew why until I /finally/ played this game. I'd recommend it to anyone, even if they're late getting into Portal and playing it like I was.10/10 would lie about cake again.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												I physically don't have the means to descibe my love of the Companion Cube. It's perfection wrapped up into a single cube. Unfortunately, it never got to taste the cake. . . . But neither did I. You see, the Companion Cube and I share a very strong bond of love, which the Companion Cube . . .Um, yeah, the Companion Cube is the most loveable item/character in all of video games. Yep.So, fan service out of the way, here's a small review.The game's amazing. You know how you see a nice game, but being someone that doesn't have money to burn, you read some reviews to see what the game's about. You eventually just read the negative reviews to find out reasons why you wouldn't want the game. After reading, you'll probably make a desicion based on what you read some time later.Well . . . it's a bit different from that when the game has 98% positive reviews (might vary as time goes on past this review). It's kind of just:  So, do I want this game now, or later? But if it's a game that's really good, but you're not particularly fond of (some people just don't like Counter-Strike), then maybe you won't buy it.But Portal is a game for everyone. Should take 10-15 hours to 100% the game. It's probably the most innovative puzzle game. Playing through the whole game multiple times is still entertaining. The game is so exceptional that you shouldn't even be reading reviews; instead, eat cake or aquire more affection towards your Companion Cube.I fully recommend the game.Like, to everyone.There is nothing greater than the Companion Cube. Cake is less than the Companion Cube. Companion Cube love.Companion Cube.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Portal was the first game I played on Steam, and what brought me back to PC gaming after a childhood of Nintendo. Its dark humor and soundtrack give it a distinct tone that can't be found even in Portal 2. The puzzles are fairly good, with the challenge mode versions requiring more thought. The character of GLaDOS is what makes this game fantastic. The portals are an interesting puzzle mechanic, but without GLaDOS this game would have little character. Its spiritual ancestor, Narbacular Drop, is what this game would be without its story. And Narbacular Drop has almost nothing. The story arc is compelling and draws you into the game.Please get this game. It's worth it.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												This game is easily amongst my top 5 favorite games, and is my second favorite game on the PC (after Civilization 5). This is a unique game; a 3D, first-person puzzle game revolving around portals, as the name would suggest. These portals, unlike those in most games in the world, are not the kind of stationary portal that glows green and causes you to reload the level when you go through it. No, these are more akin to holes in the wall. Holes that don't go through the wall, but do have another side; a side on another wall. Think of it less like a magical teleporter and more like a high-tech doorway.Not only can you see through portals and walk through them without having to stop and load anything, these portals are also physically accurate: momentum is conserved between portals. For example. if you fall a long way into a portal on the ground, and the other portal is, say, on the ground next to it, you'll be launched upwards out the other portal. This consequence of accurate physics is used to complete many levels in the game, so they also worked in acceleration due to gravity and terminal velocities, both of which are accurate to a surprising degree. The end result of this is one of the most immersive experiences I have ever had, based around something that had only ever served to break a game's immersion in all prior games and most subsequent games.SPOILER ALERT: If you haven't played the game, do not read the rest of this review!In addition to the seamless physics, this game also has a compelling story and an amazing atmosphere. The game makes you feel lonely. GLaDOS seems not like a person and more like a simple computer program. It's like someone put Siri on the intercom system. Even as the game progresses and you realize that GLaDOS is not just malicious, but also sentient, she still doesn't seem human. She seems more like an AI gone haywire. Not to mention, you've already left her control when she starts acting intelligent. And she is the only voice you ever hear in the game. The only other human is Ratman, who you never see or know by name; all you get is the occasional graffiti arrow or warning outside of the testing chambers when the goal or path is unclear.Speaking of Ratman and his helpful hints, may I just say that with the exception of one incident, the game gives you just enough information to progress. Not so much information that the puzzle is rendered simple, but not so little that you have to spend half an hour trying every possible option until something works. That one incident I mentioned, by the way? It's my only fault with the game. In conclusion, Portal is not perfect; no game can be. But this is as close to perfect as a puzzle game of this nature could get, and this game is worth every penny. I give it a 10 out of 10.

Posted: October 1, 2013
												Easily one of the best games I've ever played.  I should have played it when it came out, but better late than never!  The ending song was stuck in my head for days after I finished it.  It combines two of my favorite genres - puzzles and FPS - in a wonderful way.  Instead of shooting bullets, you use your gun to create portals that you must use in creative ways to traverse to the next level.  There are a few secrets, too, that can net you some achievments, and one of them makes the game more challenging since you have to find an object and bring it to a specific location before completing the level. The best part about the game, however,  is GLaDOS, who is by far one of the best video game characters ever made. Considering that you mostly hear her voice, that's pretty impressive.  She has more of a personality and background in the sequel but I like the first one a little better since you aren't aware of what she's really like at first. Like Half-Life 2, the game tells its story during the action instead of using cutscenes, which gives it more subtlety.  I'm not against cutscenes unless they are too long, but they do tend to make the game less immersive.  I can't really say anything bad about this game, but if it weren't so short (it was originally part of The Orange Box package, so that's understandable) it would have been my #1 game on Steam.  I like System Shock 2 a little more, so I guess that means I have a thing for evil A.I.s.
