Posted: April 27, 2014
"Portal is the original game of the Portal series. It is a single-player puzzle-based video game developed by Valve and released as part of The Orange Box on October 9, 2007 for Microsoft Windows and Xbox 360..."  This game is a unique classic and It's hard to find a gamer today who has not heard of it or some of it's references in our culture. It focuses on several key elements which make this game a masterpiece of it's time:  - Short gameplay set in an unknown and intriguing environment that sets perfectly with the story's theme. - A unique and fast paced plot filled with humor that gives little to no answers and raises a mountain of questions. - It offers advanced and bonus maps as well as achievements that act as a challenge arc that complement the main story's somewhat simple puzzles.  Most prevalent critique of this game is that it's gameplay is too short and the obstacles are too simple. This is true, but in my opinion that is not a bad thing, because after the release of it's sequel this game should not be observed as something separate from it. We should judge games and the content they brings based on the era in which they were developed and the intent of their release. And the original Portal should be considered a 'Tech demo', and something that is intended to be build up on with a sequel.Something that should also be mentioned is that this game has Controller Support which means you can play it comfortably with a gamepad. It also includes a Level Editor and welcomes native modifications since it includes a Source SDK.  With all that being said, I would recommend this game as it is an excellent introduction into the Portal series and you will finally find out why the cake is a damn lie!

Posted: December 14, 2014
												        The more I played this game, the more I liked it. The more engaging it got. The more curious I became about what was going on in these test chambers. It only took me 4 or 5 hours to beat, yet somehow Valve managed to compress a truly remarkable amount of content into those hours. I didn't expect for a puzzle game to have such a fascinating story, which I won't tell you about for fear of ruining it. Nor did I anticipate the hilarious dialogue (or really, monologue), or the unique gameplay, or the unsettling atmosphere. Graphics are nothing special, but trust me when I say it doesn't matter: they don't bring down the game as a whole.        Before playing this game, I read on several websites that it's the best game of all time. I'm not sure I agree with that bold statement, but I was so unprecedently stunned by Portal, I can understand how someone could make a case for it.        Outstanding game that everyone who owns Steam, or just exists, should play. 9/10, think with portals!

Posted: March 11
												For The Cake:1 2/3 cups all-purpose flour1 1/2 cups granulated sugar2/3 cup unsweetened cocoa powder1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda1 teaspoon salt1 1/2 cups buttermilk1/2 cup vegetable shortening 2 eggs1 teaspoon vanilla extract1/2 cup Kirsch (cherry liqueur)For the filling:¼ cup Kirsch2 cans sour cherries3 cups heavy whipping cream¼ cup confectioners' sugar3 tablespoons cocoaFor the Garnish:1 semisweet chocolate bar, frozenAt least 8 maraschino cherries (no stems)One white candleDirections1) Preheat your oven to 350°F.2) Grease and flour two 8 inch cakepans, or line with parchment paper.3) Sift together the flour, the cocoa, the baking soda and the salt. Set this aside.4) Beat the shortening and sugar together until they are fluffy. Add the eggs an vanilla and beat thoroughly.5) Slowly beat in the flour mixture, occasionally alternating with the buttermilk. Beat until combined.6) Pour the batter into the cakepans.7) Bake for about 35 or 40 minutes (or until a a fork or a wooden pick comes out clean when inserted into the cake. Let the cake cool completely. The cake will be easier to cut if you keep it in the fridge for a few hours before cutting.8) After the cake has cooled, cut each layer in half (horizontally) to make four total layers. Sprinkle the layers with the 1/2 cup of Kirsch.9) Drain the canned cherries in a colander to remove most of the juice.10) Beat the whipping cream with confectioners' sugar until it thickens to desired texture.11) Put a small amount of the cream/sugar mixture aside for garnish. Mix the cocoa powder into the remaining majority of the whipped cream frosting.12) Place one cake layer on the serving dish you wish to use. Spread about one 6th of the whipped cream on the layer, and strew a third of the cherries on top of the whipped cream.13) Add the second cake layer on top of the first. Spread one 6th of the whipped cream on the second layer and 1/3 of the cherries on top.14) Add the third cake layer. Spread 1/6 of the whipped cream on that and add the remaining cherries.15) Top with the last cake layer. Frost the top and sides of the cake with remaining frosting.16) Use a potato peeler on the chocolate to create thin shaves. Gently pat the chocolate shaves on to the sides and top of the cake, completely coating it.17) Use the whipped cream you set aside earlier to place eight small circles around the top of the cake. Place your non-stemmed maraschino cherries on each one.18) Place white candle in the center and light. Congratulations, you have made the cake a reality!- See more at: http://www.geekychef.com/2010/09/delicious-and-moist-cake.html#sthash.LFNH9Csl.dpuf

Posted: September 18, 2015
												Let's be honest: You don't need my opinion of this game. If you know what Portal is, you already know that it's one of the most celebrated games of all time. Portal is so tight and so polished that there's really nothing I can say at this point that hasn't been said. It's phenomenal and it's absolutely worth your time.If I had to critique it at all, it's simply that this version isn't 100% accurate to the original. Specifically, the transmission achievement that hamfists a radio into every chamber can get obnoxious -- not because the radios are difficult to get, but rather because they're difficult to avoid. Hearing the salsa version of Still Alive so frequently cuts the ambience of the game  and ungracefully extracts you from the mystery and intrigue. If you aren't able to ignore it, it's a mood killer, and I wish it had been a game option I could turn on and off rather than an automatic addition.But it's clearly not enough to stop me from playing the game. GLaDOS is enough motivation for me to play pretty much anything she's appeared in, and she should be for you, too. Portal is only a couple hours long even for a beginner, so take it for a spin. If you like puzzles and love a good story, you won't regret it.

												Portal was the first game I played on Steam, and what brought me back to PC gaming after a childhood of Nintendo. Its dark humor and soundtrack give it a distinct tone that can't be found even in Portal 2. The puzzles are fairly good, with the challenge mode versions requiring more thought. The character of GLaDOS is what makes this game fantastic. The portals are an interesting puzzle mechanic, but without GLaDOS this game would have little character. Its spiritual ancestor, Narbacular Drop, is what this game would be without its story. And Narbacular Drop has almost nothing. The story arc is compelling and draws you into the game.Please get this game. It's worth it.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												This game impressed me by how motivating it is. I easily get frustrated with puzzles these days, but the way the challenges are designed, you just know that it's not really a task of managing intellectual complexity, but you just have to look through the illusion of complexity and see the simple solution. It's fun to analyze a problem step-by-step, often in reverse order, with the confidence that eventually you'll overcome it.When trying to complete Antichamber, I was tempted to use guides for solving one or two of the problems, but not in Portal. In Portal, when I spent too much time on a puzzle, I just gave it a rest and continued the next day.So this is a very good game for cultivating mental resolve without overburdening you. I wouldn't want to miss my play time of Portal.

												7/10 - Short and sweet fps puzzlerPros:- The "portal" mechanic is very well done and allows for many inventive techinques.- The game is paced very well and gets you used to the mind-bending world of portal-creating before expecting a lot from you.- Although a short game (it took me 2-3 hours to beat), the challenges are nothing to scoff at: You will need to become a Portal expert before you will be able to take the Gold (took me .Cons:- Going through two floor portals can be quite disorienting and messes up the controls (due to continual automated attempts to flip the character upright)

Posted: December 14, 2014
												        The more I played this game, the more I liked it. The more engaging it got. The more curious I became about what was going on in these test chambers. It only took me 4 or 5 hours to beat, yet somehow Valve managed to compress a truly remarkable amount of content into those hours. I didn't expect for a puzzle game to have such a fascinating story, which I won't tell you about for fear of ruining it. Nor did I anticipate the hilarious dialogue (or really, monologue), or the unique gameplay, or the unsettling atmosphere. Graphics are nothing special, but trust me when I say it doesn't matter: they don't bring down the game as a whole.        Before playing this game, I read on several websites that it's the best game of all time. I'm not sure I agree with that bold statement, but I was so unprecedently stunned by Portal, I can understand how someone could make a case for it.        Outstanding game that everyone who owns Steam, or just exists, should play. 9/10, think with portals!

Even if you don't enjoy games involving puzzle, I think you'd be able to make an exception for this game. Also, you're missing tons of references by not playing this game. Posted: March 11
												For The Cake:1 2/3 cups all-purpose flour1 1/2 cups granulated sugar2/3 cup unsweetened cocoa powder1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda1 teaspoon salt1 1/2 cups buttermilk1/2 cup vegetable shortening 2 eggs1 teaspoon vanilla extract1/2 cup Kirsch (cherry liqueur)For the filling:¼ cup Kirsch2 cans sour cherries3 cups heavy whipping cream¼ cup confectioners' sugar3 tablespoons cocoaFor the Garnish:1 semisweet chocolate bar, frozenAt least 8 maraschino cherries (no stems)One white candleDirections1) Preheat your oven to 350°F.2) Grease and flour two 8 inch cakepans, or line with parchment paper.3) Sift together the flour, the cocoa, the baking soda and the salt. Set this aside.4) Beat the shortening and sugar together until they are fluffy. Add the eggs an vanilla and beat thoroughly.5) Slowly beat in the flour mixture, occasionally alternating with the buttermilk. Beat until combined.6) Pour the batter into the cakepans.7) Bake for about 35 or 40 minutes (or until a a fork or a wooden pick comes out clean when inserted into the cake. Let the cake cool completely. The cake will be easier to cut if you keep it in the fridge for a few hours before cutting.8) After the cake has cooled, cut each layer in half (horizontally) to make four total layers. Sprinkle the layers with the 1/2 cup of Kirsch.9) Drain the canned cherries in a colander to remove most of the juice.10) Beat the whipping cream with confectioners' sugar until it thickens to desired texture.11) Put a small amount of the cream/sugar mixture aside for garnish. Mix the cocoa powder into the remaining majority of the whipped cream frosting.12) Place one cake layer on the serving dish you wish to use. Spread about one 6th of the whipped cream on the layer, and strew a third of the cherries on top of the whipped cream.13) Add the second cake layer on top of the first. Spread one 6th of the whipped cream on the second layer and 1/3 of the cherries on top.14) Add the third cake layer. Spread 1/6 of the whipped cream on that and add the remaining cherries.15) Top with the last cake layer. Frost the top and sides of the cake with remaining frosting.16) Use a potato peeler on the chocolate to create thin shaves. Gently pat the chocolate shaves on to the sides and top of the cake, completely coating it.17) Use the whipped cream you set aside earlier to place eight small circles around the top of the cake. Place your non-stemmed maraschino cherries on each one.18) Place white candle in the center and light. Congratulations, you have made the cake a reality!- See more at: http://www.geekychef.com/2010/09/delicious-and-moist-cake.html#sthash.LFNH9Csl.dpuf

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Portal was the first game I played on Steam, and what brought me back to PC gaming after a childhood of Nintendo. Its dark humor and soundtrack give it a distinct tone that can't be found even in Portal 2. The puzzles are fairly good, with the challenge mode versions requiring more thought. The character of GLaDOS is what makes this game fantastic. The portals are an interesting puzzle mechanic, but without GLaDOS this game would have little character. Its spiritual ancestor, Narbacular Drop, is what this game would be without its story. And Narbacular Drop has almost nothing. The story arc is compelling and draws you into the game.Please get this game. It's worth it.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												This game is easily amongst my top 5 favorite games, and is my second favorite game on the PC (after Civilization 5). This is a unique game; a 3D, first-person puzzle game revolving around portals, as the name would suggest. These portals, unlike those in most games in the world, are not the kind of stationary portal that glows green and causes you to reload the level when you go through it. No, these are more akin to holes in the wall. Holes that don't go through the wall, but do have another side; a side on another wall. Think of it less like a magical teleporter and more like a high-tech doorway.Not only can you see through portals and walk through them without having to stop and load anything, these portals are also physically accurate: momentum is conserved between portals. For example. if you fall a long way into a portal on the ground, and the other portal is, say, on the ground next to it, you'll be launched upwards out the other portal. This consequence of accurate physics is used to complete many levels in the game, so they also worked in acceleration due to gravity and terminal velocities, both of which are accurate to a surprising degree. The end result of this is one of the most immersive experiences I have ever had, based around something that had only ever served to break a game's immersion in all prior games and most subsequent games.SPOILER ALERT: If you haven't played the game, do not read the rest of this review!In addition to the seamless physics, this game also has a compelling story and an amazing atmosphere. The game makes you feel lonely. GLaDOS seems not like a person and more like a simple computer program. It's like someone put Siri on the intercom system. Even as the game progresses and you realize that GLaDOS is not just malicious, but also sentient, she still doesn't seem human. She seems more like an AI gone haywire. Not to mention, you've already left her control when she starts acting intelligent. And she is the only voice you ever hear in the game. The only other human is Ratman, who you never see or know by name; all you get is the occasional graffiti arrow or warning outside of the testing chambers when the goal or path is unclear.Speaking of Ratman and his helpful hints, may I just say that with the exception of one incident, the game gives you just enough information to progress. Not so much information that the puzzle is rendered simple, but not so little that you have to spend half an hour trying every possible option until something works. That one incident I mentioned, by the way? It's my only fault with the game. In conclusion, Portal is not perfect; no game can be. But this is as close to perfect as a puzzle game of this nature could get, and this game is worth every penny. I give it a 10 out of 10.

												This game is a great game, the second one is better but i'm talking about this one. In this game you play as a girl named Chell, and you use a thing called a quantnam space hole genorator or something like that aka the "portal gun". In the game you have to deafeat the homosidal robot: GLaDoS (yes, you have to capidalize those letters). GLaDoS will place you in rooms with the portal gun and in those rooms will be filled with the folowing items: buttons, cubes, lasers, acids, doors and diffrent colered walls. White walls you can shoot portals onto and black walls you cannot. The rooms you will be put into are called test chambers. They are each filled with different puzzels and they get harder as you progress. Also just to note there are things that shoot you: Turrets, and anamate objects that are freindly: Companion cubes.The game isn't perrfect so I give it an 8.5 out of 10

Posted: March 29, 2015
												A really long time I had wondered what's so great about this game. I thought it was some kind of shooter and well..I'm not a big fan of that kind of genre.I was wrong. SO WRONG!Portal is far away from a shooter. It's a really clever puzzle game with a lot of (mostly black) humor and an unique gameplay (first person). Each level is great to play and challenges your brain. You have to solve challenges by shooting portals to maneuver objects or even yourself through each chamber.I'd recommend to play it with a gamepad, since some stuff is easier to do with. In particular if you are an achievement hunter.The only negative point for me is; it's too short! There are 19 chambers, 6 advanced chambers and 6 bonus chambers. And if you got the hang out of the game, well, it can be over quickly. (But luckily there is Portal 2 and some nice Mods.)So if you like puzzle games and got a glimmer of black humor, Portal is perfect for you.

Posted: March 31
												Adds to what makes The Orange Box great.Portal is a first person...puzzle game? That's right. Not only is Portal unique in being a first person game with virtualing NO "shooting", but it's first person POV makes its puzzles all-the-more emersive. Portal's story is set in the Aperture testing labs, a tie-in to the Half-Life series lore, where a rogue AI with a morbid sense of humor is attempting to off its latest guinea pig. You control Michelle, a test subject who slowly uncovers just what went haywire, why trying not to join the previous test subjects in oblivion. With some very clever puzzles and a twisted sense of humor, Portal builds upon the lore of the Half-Life series in some really cool ways.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												Introducing a simple mechanic and making it an unforgettable main feature is something common to video games.  We've seen it in the past with such simple things as leaping, turning back time while on a limited clock, and other innovators.  Portal, somehow, makes leaping from one location to another near-instantaneously - simple teleportation with two exits - an amazing experience.  While the game is fun and the puzzles brainwracking, it's Valve's writing that'll keep you coming back for more.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												Portal is a puzzle game released by Valve in late 2007 along with The Orange Box, it was intended to be something of a stocking stuffer as an apology for there not being a Half-Life 2: Episode 3. It wound up becoming the most successful game of the lot.The game was developed by a small team whom Gabe Newell imediately hired after seeing their previous work "Narbacular Drop", The precursor to Portal.Spoiling as little as possible: You are a woman named Chell who has awoken from what can only be assumed is a cryosleep in the Aperture Science Enrichment Centre. You are greeted by a voice called GLaDOS or "Genetic Lifeform and Disc Operating System" who tells you that you're about to take part in a serious of tests involving the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device. (Or just the Portal Gun.)The gameplay is simple. You guide Chell through a series of puzzles contained within the game's 19 test chambers with naturally progressing difficulty, though, the difficulty of the game as a whole isn't that bad, the puzzles aren't mind boggling and the closest thing you'll come to common enemies are these adorable white spherical turrets. The game runs on the Source Engine and it's acurate physics simulations. This is shown off in many of the game's mechanics most notably momentum based puzzles which like the rest of the game is sound. The game is quite easy once you know the solutions to the puzzles, beatable in just three hours on the first playthrough and if you're like me can be beaten in as little as 35 minutes when you decide to try and speedrun it. (or even less if you're persistent enough, I've seen people do it in as little as 9 minutes.) Don't worry about that first playthrough though, as you'll miss out on the game's fantastic writing and pacing if you do. Ellen McLain gives a brilliant performance as GLaDOS with well crafted dark humour anybody can enjoy.SPOILER TERRITORY AHEADAfter all is said and done and you reach the end of Chamber 19 you're sent into an incinerator. Most of GLaDOS' dialogue up to this point sounded as though it could have been pre-recorded but it now becomes aparant she's been watching you the whole time and is aware of your escape after you... do that. You make your way through the less sterile maintenance areas of the facility with GLaDOS trying desperatley to convince you to go back with promise of cake. You eventually come across an office area after a turret battle and become ever more convinced that GLaDOS is the reason you've not met any other humans. You then cross a bridge into her chamber. The hulking machine now resorting to death threats. You then do battle, redirecting rockets through portals and into her body. You then incinerate some important pieces of her until she's destroyed. You're shown a brief glimpse of the outside world before being dragged back into Aperture's walls. The credits roll to "Still Alive" written by Jonathan Coulton. It's a sweet little tune, I'll leave it at that. Go listen to it yourself after beating the game.NOW LEAVING SPOILER TERRITORYThe game has 15 achievements for you to get in order to claim you've 100% complete the game. To get some you'll have to play through the game's extra modes. Challenge mode puts you back into a few chambers except trying to beat it under one of three conditions: Least Portals, Least Steps, Least Time. Getting every achievement will require some very good knowlege of the game's mechanics and the way the chambers are designed. Good Luck getting the Vanilla Crazy Cake achievement, this requires getting the highest rank for each challenge and for each chamber. The other mode are the Advanced Chambers. You're dropped back into chambers 13-18 except they've been made much harder to complete. To get the Aperture Science achievement you will need to beat all six.After you've done it all? Well. I'm kind. I shall now list some notable mods and map packs for Portal which you should definately give a look:MODS:Very hard logical puzzles: Portal ProBullsh!t flinging puzzles: Portal PreludeSomething Different: Portal UnityGreat Aesthetics and New Mechanics: Blue PortalsJust... More Portal with little in terms of new mechanics: Gamma EnergyEnergy Pellets, Just... Energy Pellets: RexauraAcid Trip: Hetzchase NailwayMAP PACKS:Another.Test.SubjectPortal: The Flash Version Map PackPortal: Underground Story

Posted: August 1, 2014
												This game, amazing. Best storyline from a game I have EVER played, and the puzzle mechanic with portals is AMAZING.This might be long, but here I go:Think with PortalsThat is what you are always encouraged to do, and for good reasoning. You are being tested by a demonic AI named GLaDOS(Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System) who took over Aperture Science and forced it into a infinite testing cycle, where the character you play as, Chell, is no. 1498 on the to be tested list. That is, until a scientist who survived the neurotoxins (more on that later) Named Doug Rattmann, or The Rat Man, noticed she was the one who could end all of this, and switched her to the number one spot before GLaDOS could notice. Although the Rat Man is never in the Portal Games in any form, he does leave little dens for Chell to find, and they usually include hints that will be needed later on like...The Cake Is A LieThe Cake is a LieThe Cake is a LieThe Cake is a LieThe Cake is a LieThe Cake is a LieThis is one of the many scrawlings/writings that The Rat Man will leave for Chell to find. This hints that GLaDOS is encouraging Chell that there will be cake after the testing is over, but Doug is telling Chell to ignore GLaDOS.GLaDOS's ActivationThe only reason why GLaDOS is there is because the original founder of Aperture Science, Cave Johnson, was about to die. So the Aperture Science team had to gather moon rocks to set up a AI for Cave Johnson to be inside, so he could control Aperture Science from there. But Cave Johnson soon realized that the moon rocks are speeding up the ''inevitable'' so he told his workers that he wasn't going to make it, and instead to make the AI so that it would be more feminine, and have a personality more like his assistant, Caroline. So on the annual bring your daughter to work day, GLaDOS was activated, and INSTANTLY became self-aware, and flooded ''The Enrichment Center'' with deadly neurotoxins. Doug Rattman was the only known worker to have survived, along with Chell.OK, now you know the events before and during the Portal game, back to my ratings.Graphics: 95/100Gameplay: 99/100Lasting Appeal: 90/100 (However replay-ability is near 0)Storyline: 100/100Humor/Dialogue: 99/100My rating: 9.66/10.A must buy. But if you like it (Which you should!!) Make sure to buy Portal 2.Just one last thing, make sure to remember:THE CAKE IS A LIE.

												The game was a triumph.I'm making a note here: TIME WELL SPENT.It's hard to overstate my satisfaction.The original Portal.It's short and sweet; just like a cake.For all of the enjoyment,That everybody gets.But theres no sense crying cause of a little hate.You just try for yourself; see if it's really great!And when the game gets done, and you put away your gun,You'll be happy that you have survived.I'm not even lying;I'm being so sincere right now.Even though this game is short, and quirky.And innovative.And has a really cool, evil villain.As it ended I smiled because, I could play Portal 2!Now these thumbs and fingers point towards the sky.And I'm pretty sure not one of them was a lie!So I'm GLaD I bought this!Its on my "favorites" list!I recommend this fantastic game.Go ahead and play it...I think you'll enjoy this puzzle game.Maybe you'll buy Portal 2.Maybe PS:Mel.Mel's a good game, but it's fan made.Anyway this game is great!It's so clever and dark.Look at me still talking when there's science to do!When I play co-op, I could maybe help you!You've got puzzles to do.GLaDOS is waiting on you!Get in there and complete some tests!And believe me this game is just great.9 years later this game is just great.I've speed-ran it; this game is just great!And when your dying this game will be great.And when your dead this game will be just great.Portal 1.Portal 1.

Posted: October 4, 2014
												This game is a classic, even though i never played it before now, it is referenced in so much and has so many tribute videos, art, webcomics, etc. Needless to say that my exceptations were high when i started it and in most cases expectations are never fulfilled.Not with this game. It is simply in its own class of greatnes. It is one of those games you must have played.The concept is simple and effective, it's a FPP (First Person Puzzler) and while the puzzles are not that hard, you do need to stop and think about them once in a while, which makes it just all more compelling (whats the fun when there is no challenge, right?).Is it all good then? No, there are some lesser points to the game. First, it is really short and over before you know it. Second, some of the puzzles require this second perfect timing or pixel perfect jumping to complete and that can be frustrating sometimes (or perhaps i didn't solve them right?).

Posted: December 3, 2015
												I came to this franchise very, very late. My first experience in the "Portal" universe was playing co-op in "Portal 2", which I finished, and enjoyed, albeit more for the satisfaction of finishing such a complicated game than for the story.I did enjoy the game, although it is quite difficult. The story left me with a lot of questions. GLADoS' voice acting was beautiful, the game looks quite polished, and I like it a lot more than what I've experienced thus far in "Portal 2"'s solo campaign, although I do enjoy that game, too.I also had the luck to completely miss hearing (within my recollection) any version of "Still Alive" before finishing the game, so when the credits rolled, I was quite pleasantly surprised to hear it for the first time. I adore the song, so that was a treat. Probably the first time I've sat through the entire credits of a video game. Considering how much fanart and memes of the cake references, "It's a lie!", GLADoS, Chell, the companion cube, and stuff from "Portal 2" I've come across, that's surprising.All in all a nice puzzle game. If you haven't played either of these, wait for the sales. They go on sale pretty much every time there is a sale, and they're often sold together pretty inexpensively.
